holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court investigated agency under unpleaded agreement instead of addressing petition grounds or leaving to statutory machinery.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 is extensive, but normally the High Court does not exercise that jurisdiction by entertaining petitions against the orders of taxing authorities when the statute provides a remedy by way of an appeal or other proceeding thereby by-passing the statutory machinery.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 is extensive, but numbermally the High Court does number exercise that jurisdiction by entertaining petitions against the or- ders of taxing authorities, when the statute under which tax is sought to be levied provides a remedy by way of an appeal or other proceeding to a party aggrieved and thereby by-pass the statutory machinery.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature provides self-contained machinery for tax disputes; writ jurisdiction not to bypass appeals/revisions.

holdings.text: The High Court has jurisdiction to decide whether a statute is within legislative competence, defies constitutional restrictions, infringes fundamental rights, or involves jurisdictional/procedural errors by taxing authority.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has undoubtedly jurisdiction to decide whether a statute under which a tax is sought to be levied is within the legislative companypetence of the Legislature enacting it or whether the statute defies companystitutional restrictions or infringes any fundamental rights, or whether the taxing authority has arrogated to himself power which he does number possess, or has companymitted a serious error of procedure which has affected the validity of his companyclusion or even where the taxing authority threatens to recover tax on an interpretation of the statute which is erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exceptional grounds for writ intervention despite statutory remedies.
